newsitem.title: USA: Sealy Corp gets $275 mln loan to complete recap.
newsitem.headline: Sealy Corp gets $275 mln loan to complete recap.

text.p: Sealy Corp, a Cleveland-based bedding manufacturer, announced on Friday that it had closed on a $275 million credit facility that will allow it to successfully conclude a recapitalization.
The secured revolving credit facility was arranged by BankAmerica Corp's Bank of America
"With the recapitalization concluded, we can now focus all of our energies on strengthening and expanding the business," stated Ron Jones, Sealy's president and CEO in a written statement.

Sealy, a privately held company, will use the new credit facility to make a $99.8 million special dividend payment to shareholders as well as to refinance outstanding bank debt, said Ron Stolle, the company's vice president and treasurer.
Stolle declined to specify the amount of bank debt to be refinanced, saying the sum would be disclosed in an upcoming filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
He said the company will also use the borrowing to pay $4 million in consent fees to holders of the company's $200 million senior subordinated notes due 2003.

Sealy agreed to pay the fees to bondholders on a pro rata basis in exchange for their consents to modify certain provisions in the notes' indenture that would have restricted the company from paying the dividend to shareholders.
To obtain bondholder consents, the company also agreed to increase the coupon on the notes to 10.25 percent from 9.50 percent as well as to raise the notes' call premium.
The company stated it received consents from 99.3 percent of qualifying note holders.

Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's are currently considering downgrading the B1/B-plus ratings on the notes as a result of the recapitalization, according to statements from both rating agencies.
When asked about the current rating agency reviews, Stolle said, "We can't speak for (the agencies), but we are making formal updated presentations to them next week."
